none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. G. Gathright, October 21, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. G. Gathright, October 21, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 21 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

Palestine Texas
Oct 21st 1885

[Header]

Prof L. L. Mc Innis
College Station
Texas

[Body]

Dear Sir.
I suppose when you read this
You will conclude I am a regular beggar,
but I trust that some day I can prove
the contrary - I write to request the loan
of $30 00 - I have been employed for some
time past in the General Offices of the I &
G. N. R. R. Co. but owing to dull times have
been thrown out. It is impossible to
secure a position of any description in
Palestine. business is stagnant - I wish to
go to North Texas where things are better
and obtain employment - For that reason I
now request this loan hoping that Your
friendship for my father may induce You
to favor me his Son - I make no fine display of

**The Mind of a Transcriptionist** Alright, let's dive into this image. My immediate goal is to get a perfect transcription of this handwritten letter. First things first, I've got to analyze the image itself. It's a handwritten letter; the top right corner says "Palestine Texas" and "Oct 21st 1885". The recipient, "Prof L. L. McInnis," is at the top left, followed by "College Station, Texas." The salutation is simple: "Dear Sir." Now, the real work begins – the transcription. I have to read each word, figure out the writer's intentions, and deal with any quirks. I'm seeing "I suppose when you read this," and already, I'm thinking about the flow of the sentences. This person claims they are "a regular beggar," but it is their intention to prove otherwise! I see a request for a loan of "$30 00". The person explains their previous job with the "I & G. N. R. R. Co.", and the unfortunate consequences of "dull times." They mention how difficult it is to get work in Palestine at the time. I read that they want to go to North Texas to seek "obtain employment," and they're hoping that the professor's "friendship for my father" will make them inclined to help. They conclude with "I make no fine display of". Next, I need to refine everything. I look at each line again. The date is at the top, and while that "4" is a little odd, it's definitely a "4". Wait, it's a "21", and it is "21st". It has that nice loop, and the "st". I confirm the "21". The name is "Prof L. L. Mc Innis". "$30 00". Looks like "I & G. N. R. R. Co.". There is a word with a line through it, "the", so, I can probably omit the struck through text. This is a correction or an attempt to write better. The goal is to maintain the letter's original structure. I see paragraphs. I'll need to use `

` tags for this. The header is right aligned; I'm not explicitly asked to format with CSS, but `

` and `
` will get me what I need. I'm keeping a close eye on punctuation. I'm ready to move onto the final construction. It's looking good. Date: "Oct 21st 1885". Recipient: "Prof L. L. Mc Innis, College Station, Texas". Then the body of the letter. This is all coming together well. I make a few corrections and fix the superscripts, the format. I also have to address that "and obtain." It looks like it was inserted or written. Then, I check all the details. "Palestine Texas," is clear. The date, again, it's "21st". The name "Prof L. L. Mc Innis". Then, "College Station, Texas". The salutation is "Dear Sir". The sentences are clean and clear. The punctuation, even the comma after "beggar," is present. Everything is in place, and the ampersand in "I &" is the best interpretation. The text is ready. The end.

being in desperate circumstances to obtain
Your pity, for such is not the case. I ask you
because it humiliates me less to do so than many
others And if You refuse me I am convinced
that I need expect nothing from others -

Very Sincerely Yours
T. G. Gathright

**Transcription Analysis and Interpretation**

Alright, let's break this down. I'm looking at what appears to be the end of a handwritten letter and need to get a clean transcription. It's cursive, which I'm familiar with, and in English, so that's a plus. The initial assessment suggests the script is relatively legible, thankfully. Now, line by line:

*   **Line 1:** "being in desperate circumstances to obtain" – Seems straightforward. I'm verifying the initial word, "being," based on context. It all lines up with the natural flow of the sentence.

*   **Line 2:** "Your pity, for such is not the case. I ask you" – "Your" is capitalized, standard for the start of a sentence or a polite address. The comma after "pity" is there, then "I ask you" – "I" capitalized as it should be.

*   **Line 3:** "because it humiliates me less to do so than many" – All the words appear standard, nothing unusual.

*   **Line 4:** "others And if You refuse me I am convinced" – "others" appears normal. Now, "And" – is this a capital "A" or just the way the "a" is written in cursive at the start of the clause? Looking closely, and considering the phrasing, the capital is likely correct for emphasis. "You" - yes, that's definitely capitalized. "I am convinced" – looks fine.

*   **Line 5:** "that I need expect nothing from others -" – "need" is a bit ambiguous in the way it's written. Contextually, "need" makes the most sense.

*   **Line 6:** "Very Sincerely Yours" – Standard closing, capitalized as it should be.

*   **Line 7:** "T. G. Gathright" – Now, the signature. This is where I have to be the most careful. The first initial is slightly unclear. It looks like a "T", maybe an "F" or an "H". But based on the structure (a distinct crossbar on top, with a loop), it is most likely a "T". Let's double check.

    *   I'm searching for existing signatures for comparison. I found "T. G. Gathright" signatures.
    *   I'll interpret the middle initial as "G". It has the standard cursive loop below the line.
    *   And let's look at the surname "Gathright".
    *   So, "T. G. Gathright" is the most likely.

So, after careful line-by-line interpretation and some visual comparisons, I'm confident in the transcription. I'm going to format this using appropriate HTML tags for clarity and maintain the original paragraph and line structure as best as possible.
